An insider's primary checking account usually will reflect bi-weekly payroll deposits and normal household bills, ATM withdrawals, and debt payments.

  • A large deposit could be from an asset sale or other deposit transfer, but frequent, large, or out-of-the ordinary items should be traced.
  • Large, unexplained deposits could potentially be an indication of illegal loan proceeds, loan kickbacks, or other suspicious transactions. Trace the source of suspicious deposits by requesting copies of the item(s) comprising the deposit.
  • If suspicious activities are suspected, a review of insider account statements should cover an increased time period.
    • In cases where the primary account is not at the bank and activities

indicate further research is warranted, other bank account statements may be available during other examinations of state nonmember banks or through coordination with other regulatory agencies. Contact your Regional Office prior to requesting such information. Check if SARs or CTRs have been filed at other banks on the subjects of your review.
